The Extended Integer (XInt) Library

The Not-a-Number Value

Sometimes it's useful for a variable to have a value that doesn't represent any proper value, to indicate that it hasn't been specified or that there was an error in a calculation. For that purpose, the nothrow_integer type provides a Not-a-Number value.

To create a Not-a-Number, use the nothrow_integer::nan function. No other library function will return a Not-a-Number except under the following circumstances:

  • If a function that returns a nothrow_integer tries to throw an exception.
  • If the string-to-nothrow_integer functions are asked to convert the string "#NaN#".

The only things you can do with a Not-a-Number are:

  • Test for it, using the member function nothrow_integer::is_nan.
  • Convert it to a string, or write it to a stream. The result will be the string "#NaN#".
  • Make a copy of it.

If you attempt to do anything else with it, you will get a special value indicating failure (which will be another Not-a-Number, if the function you're calling returns a nothrow_integer).
